A function that verifies the technology is compatible with the target browser.
The process of inputting information.

A graphical representation of any portion of a database schema. It can be either a whole or partial picture of the structure of the database. It includes tables, the columns they contain, and the relationships between the tables.
A unique name that identifies a group of contacts in the Contacts list.
An item in the Windows Control Panel that enables users to access Parental Controls and other third-party parental control features, such as web filters.
A tab-like navigation link that provides access between different sections of information within the Options dialog box.
A UI element that links to the Microsoft Online Privacy Statement.
The address to which the invoice for products ordered should be sent.
A charge levied by a government on products, activities and employee or corporate income to finance government expenditure.
The ‐ character, used to break a word between syllables at the end of a line or to separate the parts of a compound word.
A feature that must be enabled in Active Directory to run incremental import of profiles.
An item on the Control Panel that provides user a comprehensive view over all roamed content, as well as ability to check on the synchronization progress of individual items.
A navigational element, usually appearing at the top of a window, that displays, and allows users to change, their current location.
A collection of properties.
An option in the Options dialog box, on the Personal tab. When the check box for this option is selected, Communicator displays this phone number along with other contact information for the user.
A license form that allows multiple installations of a particular product.
A property of an object that can be quantified numerically.
A value in a fax or phone activity that indicates the direction of the message. Typically the values are incoming or outgoing.
A device that puts text or images on paper or other print media.
A hardware-based security feature that prevents unauthorized access to a computer by providing full-volume encryption and integrity checking of boot components.
A hardware-based security feature that prevents unauthorized access to a computer by providing full-volume encryption and integrity checking of boot components.
An application that contains a linked or embedded OLE object from another application.

A means of defining the permissions of a group role within the Safe Editing feature. Administrators can create user groups and the authoring rights of each group member will be restricted according to the group permission.

A file system defined by the Optical Storage Technology Association (OSTA) that is the successor to the CD-ROM file system (CDFS). UDF is used for removable disk media like DVD, CD, and magneto-optic (MO) disks.
A hardware device, or a logical partition of it, that reads data from and writes data to hard disks.
A visual impairment that results in complete loss of vision in both eyes.
The value of an item that is based on a weighted average of the values of itself and its child entries.

A collection of computers in a networked environment that share a common database, directory database, or tree. A domain is administered as a unit with common rules and procedures, which can include security policies, and each domain has a unique name.
A request for payment for products and/or services sold.
The formal name for a company's data processing department.
An instance of a COM class.
The value that is returned on successful execution of the WebDAV LOCK method. This value is used to transact subsequent requests.
An individual stage defined in a workflow.
A button on Audio Controls that turns off mute on the user's phone.

A group of preset power-management options. For example, you can set elapsed times for putting your computer on standby and for turning off your monitor and hard disk. You save these settings as a named power scheme.

A group of preset power-management options. For example, you can set elapsed times for putting your computer on standby and for turning off your monitor and hard disk. You save these settings as a named power scheme.
The name of the dialog box in Lync and Office Communicator where a user can configure their connection settings to a server.

Content has been hashed and verified as valid against the signature. The certificate used to verify the signature is “valid” in the sense that it has a relationship to a trusted certificate authority (and isn’t expired, etc.)
A field that has certain restrictions, such as no images allowed.
A hard plastic disc on a mouse that is perpendicular to the mouse surface. It is normally located between the left and right mouse buttons and is used for scrolling.
A feature that allows the user to select from a gallery of pre-defined formatting styles and apply them quickly to tables, text, charts, drawing objects and SmartArt graphics.
A computer (or the software that runs on it) that acts as a barrier between a network and the Internet by presenting only a single network address to external sites.
The version of Microsoft Dynamics CRM available over the Internet hosted by Microsoft or a partner.
To activate a function or program, such as the release of a virus payload, in response to a specific event, date, or time.
A button in the Options dialog box, on the Personal tab, that the user clicks to enter a phone number other than a work, home, or mobile phone number.
To position objects or text relative to some point, such as the page margin.
Pertaining to a file format that allows for VBA code. Examples of file extensions for macro-enabled formats are .docm, .pptm, .xlsm.
A feature in Office Server that provides a workflow for document review.

A set of calendar enhancements that enable users to schedule people and resources quickly, efficiently, and reliably. The enhancements include the Calendar Attendant, the Resource Booking Attendant, and the Scheduling Assistant.
In Windows Media Player, a database that contains information about digital media files on a computer, a network drive, or the Internet.
The adjustment of the spacing between two characters to create the appearance of even spacing, fit text to a given space, and adjust line breaks.
An option that allows the user to manually enter a price per unit to a product that is added to a quote, order, or invoice from the product catalog.
A pricing method that determines the unit price of the product, which is calculated as a percent of the profit that you want to receive.
One character (or more) printed slightly below the baseline of surrounding text.

The core component of the Excel Server that includes the full Excel calculation functionality. It loads and saves Excel workbooks, queries and refreshes external data, calculates workbooks, and provides the calculated results to the caller.
In the context of processes or tasks that are part of an operating system or program, operating without interaction with the user while the user is working on another task.
To advance audio or video playback at a speed that is faster than normal.
A SharePoint Web Part that displays a list of tasks as well as the Gantt chart of the schedule for these tasks.

A technique used to trick computer users into revealing personal or financial information. A common online phishing scam starts with an e-mail message that appears to come from a trusted source but actually directs recipients to provide information to a fraudulent Web site.
An 8-digit code used to unlock the SIM card. A Personal Unlocking Key is a type of personal identification number (PIN).
An 8-digit code used to unlock the SIM card. A Personal Unlocking Key is a type of personal identification number (PIN).
An item provided and signed by the DCE security server that is both a proof of identity and a list of group memberships.
A category of customizations that enable configuration of client extension controls.

A facility used to house mission critical computer systems and associated components. It generally includes environmental controls (air conditioning, fire suppression, etc.), redundant/backup power supplies, redundant data communications connections and high security.
A workflow that is defined by using workflow markup language contained in XAML-formatted files. The XAML files are deployed and stored in the database.

A mechanism to integrate multiple low-level authentication schemes into a high-level API, which allows for programs that rely on authentication to be written independently of the underlying authentication scheme.
An XML or XOML file that contains the information that other programs require to instantiate and run the workflow. Optionally, any custom metadata the workflow requires to run.
A group of rules for a workflow.
The process that occurs when a workflow host calls the WorkflowRuntime.CreateWorkflow method.
An elemental unit of a workflow that represents actions and provides functionality for control flow, conditions, event handling, state management, and communication with applications and services.
A registration process that occurs when you add a workflow definition to the Microsoft Dynamics CRM database.

The combination of runtime event processing, support programs, code libraries, a scripting language, or other software to help develop and glue together the different components of a software project. In Microsoft Dynamics CRM, the plug-ins and workflows are included in a single event model.
An architectural principle where a single instance of software is used to run a service for multiple clients (tenants).
Pertaining to multiple client organizations (tenants) that are served by a single software-as-a-service (SaaS) vendor's servers.
Occurring after a core system operation has been completed.
Occurring before a core system operation occurs.
A class whose definition is split over two or more source files. Each source file contains a section of the class definition, and all parts are combined when the application is compiled.
A rule associated with an object to regulate which users can gain access to the object and in what manner. Permissions are assigned or denied by the object's owner.
A number that identifies a certain Internet application. For example, the default port number for the WWW service is 80.
An apartment that consists of exactly one thread.
An apartment that consists of exactly one thread.

A certificate that represents the public-key portion of a token-signing certificate. A verification certificate is stored in the trust policy and used by the federation server in one organization to verify that incoming security tokens have been issued by valid federation servers in the organization's farm and in other organizations.
A service or feature that renders the audio content of a television or video program as text on the screen. These captions are usually visible only if decoded or activated.
An association between a customer (account or contact) and a partner (account or contact).
A numeric or other designation appended to a product name to identify a particular release.
An effect applied to a graphical object that typically reduces the difference between the outline of the object and the graphical area next to it.
A wireless, mobile device that combines platform software, a browser, a modern chipset, and a telephone handset.
A wireless, mobile device that combines platform software, a browser, a modern chipset, and a telephone handset.
A wireless, mobile device that combines platform software, a browser, a modern chipset, and a telephone handset.
Software that provides encryption for sensitive data, such as passwords, in applications.
A Microsoft site that provides a comprehensive listing of updates that can be distributed over a corporate network.
A functionality that allows a user to push a button on a cell phone and begin voice input.
A functionality that allows a user to push a button on a cell phone and begin voice input.
A contact list, similar to an alias, that allows the talk to reach a list of users at once by the push-to-talk functionality.
A contact list, similar to an alias, that allows the talk to reach a list of users at once by the push-to-talk functionality.

A feature of Remote Desktop Services that enables the user to access a program remotely through Remote Desktop Services but have it appear as if it is running on the user's local computer. Users can run RemoteApp programs side by side with their local programs.

A type of user account that allows complete access to the computer. Administrators can make any desired changes. This account type is not recommended for daily use, and should only be used when necessary.
A voice client that is part of the Enterprise Voice solution from Microsoft; for example, Lync or Office Communicator.

A Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP) call that is routed to all of a contact’s devices that are running Office Communicator 2007. A contact can receive a Communicator call on his or her computer or on a telephony device that is configured for Office Communicator 2007.
The date when a project or task is scheduled to begin.
The name automatically assigned to an object by a program or process when the user does not specify an alternative.

A mail-enabled Active Directory group object. In Exchange 2007, a distribution group refers to all mail-enabled groups, whether they are an Active Directory security group or an Active Directory distribution group. When an e-mail message is sent to a distribution group, all members of that list receive a copy of the message.
A caller whose caller ID information is not available.
A user-defined description of a particular device.
Information about schedules and appointments that is stored in an Exchange Server 2007 user's mailbox and retrievable for display through a client interface or voice mail.
A dialog box in which a user confirms that he or she wants a specified action to occur, usually by clicking OK.
A three-digit string of numbers, such as 5.1.2., that indicates the status of an attempt to deliver an e-mail message.
The value that is applied to a specific DWORD.
A logical grouping of shared services and their supporting resources.
A measure of how closely results match a customer's search keywords.
To take out objects from a list, database, or other item, or to uninstall a program.
To continue a process or service that has been paused.
To set an entity, such as a feature, configuration, or object, back to its defaults.
To locate text or a specific item on a Web page or in a document.
A navigation button used to complete and close a wizard.

A program whose function is to install another program, either on a storage medium or in memory. An installation program, also called a setup program, might be used to guide a user through the often complex process of setting up an application for a particular combination of machine, printer, and monitor.
A group of reusable settings that describes the shared attributes and behaviors of a list item, a document, or a folder.
Conditions that users specify to limit which records are included in the result set of a query.

An e-mail message that is automatically sent by Microsoft Exchange to the owners of a mailbox or a public folder when a size limit, which is called a storage quota, for the mailbox or public folder has been exceeded or is at risk of being exceeded.
To briefly press a UI element with your fingertip or stylus to perform an activity (such as choosing an action from a menu or opening an item).

A code that credit card companies use to authorize credit card charges. For example, American Express uses a four-digit number on the front of the credit card, and Visa, MasterCard, and Discover use a three-digit number on the back.

termGrp.term: codi de validació de la targeta

descripGrp.descrip: A code that credit card companies use to authorize credit card charges. For example, American Express uses a four-digit number on the front of the credit card, and Visa, MasterCard, and Discover use a three-digit number on the back.

termGrp.term: valor de verificació de la targeta

descripGrp.descrip: A code that credit card companies use to authorize credit card charges. For example, American Express uses a four-digit number on the front of the credit card, and Visa, MasterCard, and Discover use a three-digit number on the back.

A code that credit card companies use to authorize credit card charges. For example, American Express uses a four-digit number on the front of the credit card, and Visa, MasterCard, and Discover use a three-digit number on the back.

The amount of time between the scheduled start of a task and the time when work should actually begin on the task; it is often used to resolve resource overallocations. There are two types of delay: assignment delay and leveling delay.
Data that is stored outside of the application that is currently in use.
Resolving resource conflicts or overallocations by delaying or splitting certain tasks. When Project levels a resource, its selected assignments are distributed and rescheduled.
A schedule of task start and finish dates and resource and cost data.
The degree of excellence, or the desired standards, in a product, process, or project.
A representation of the communication path between actors.
An actor's interface component through which actors communicate with other actors.
Any one-dimensional (1-D) shape that can be glued between two shapes in a drawing to connect the shapes.
To change the dimensions of a shape by dragging one of its handles after it has been selected with the pointer tool.

The quantity of a resource assigned to a task. The maximum units is the maximum number of units available for the resource. For example, if you have three plumbers, the maximum units is 300 percent or three plumbers working full-time.
Pertaining to information that shows what has actually occurred. For example, the actual start date for a task is the day that the task actually started.
The percentage of a resource's capacity that is designated for a specific assignment.
Conditions you specify to limit which records are included in the result set of a query or filter.

A feature that enables users to build robust, targeted queries that include search operators. The least complex of which are the Boolean operators many users are familiar with. In addition, customers can use advanced operators such as "contains:" or "inanchor:" or "site:" Customers can add operator upon operator and watch their query change in the search box.
A notification that is displayed to a user when user-defined criteria are met.
Software that enables parents and guardians to customize children's web experiences in order to help protect their safety and privacy online.
Software that enables parents and guardians to customize children's web experiences in order to help protect their safety and privacy online.
Software that enables parents and guardians to customize children's web experiences in order to help protect their safety and privacy online.
A product's settings that enable customers to determine how people who also use the product may interact with them.
To add a video to a blog entry by entering the embed code for the video.
HTML code that adds an object, such as a video, to a Web site, blog, or HTML page.
A UI element that links to a text box where the user can enter the embed code to add a video to his or her blog.
A list of people, invited by the user, that includes the display picture, notes, and tags for each friend.
The folder that by default receives new messages.
The folder that by default receives new messages.
A feature that enables a customer to send a text message to any contact who uses a supported mobile device.
A tool that enables a user to get another user's attention by shaking the user's conversation window and playing a sound.
The protection of Internet users from phishing fraud, indentity threat, spyware, and malware (malicious software).
A UI element that links to a Web page that displays the condition and quality of the service.
An online scan that examines a hard disk's level of fragmentation.
An online scan that examines a hard disk's level of fragmentation.
An animated greeting a customer can send to a contact.
The process of publishing photos or blog entries by sending an e-mail message to a service.
To package your publication files by using the Pack and Go Wizard.
The color or image that appears behind the content of a visual element, for example, behind the text that is displayed in a TextBox control or on your graphical user interface.
To display an object.
A Unicode character used to indicate that text is encoded in UTF-8, UTF-16 or UTF-32.
The process of sending changes in small groups instead of in a one-shot transfer of the data in its entirety.
A service, application, or device that wants to integrate into the Microsoft Sync Framework architecture.
A particular repository of information to be synchronized.
The process of determining which operations were made by one replica without knowledge of the other, such as when two replicas make local updates to the same item.
A collection of clock vector elements that represents updates to a replica. Any change that occurs between 0 and the tick count is contained in the vector.
A monotonically increasing number that is used to uniquely identify a change to an item in a replica.
A monotonically increasing number that is used to uniquely identify a change to an item in a replica.
Metadata that identifies a change made to an item in a replica. It consists of the replica key and the replica tick count for the item.
A unidirectional synchronization in which the source provider enumerates its changes and sends them to the destination provider, which applies them to its store.
A software component that allows a replica to synchronize its data with other replicas.
A software component that allows a replica to synchronize its data with other replicas.
A synchronization provider that enumerates any changes and sends them to the destination provider.
A synchronization provider that enumerates any changes and sends them to the destination provider.

A synchronization provider that provide its current knowledge, accept a list of changes from the source provider, detect any conflicts between that list and its own items, and apply changes to its data store.

A synchronization provider that provide its current knowledge, accept a list of changes from the source provider, detect any conflicts between that list and its own items, and apply changes to its data store.
A value that uniquely identifies a replica.
A 4-byte value that maps to a replica ID in a replica key map.
The set of data that is being synchronized.
A software component, such as a personal information manager or music database, that hosts a synchronization session and invokes synchronization providers to synchronize disparate data stores.
A synchronization provider and its associated replica.
The metadata about all the changes that a participant has seen and maintains.
A unit of data or metadata that is being synchronized. A typical item of data might be a file or record, whereas a typical item of metadata might be a knowledge item.

A unique identifier that is assigned to a data item. The identifier must be unique across all clients. A global identifier is a flexible identifier and so can be any format, but it is typically a GUID and an 8-byte prefix.

A unique identifier that is assigned to a data item. The identifier must be unique across all clients. A global identifier is a flexible identifier and so can be any format, but it is typically a GUID and an 8-byte prefix.
An identifier that is assigned to various synchronization entities, such as replicas. The identifier can be of fixed or variable length.
An identifier that is assigned to various synchronization entities, such as replicas. The identifier can be of fixed or variable length.
The minimal unit of data synchronization. Because all changes that have the same consistency unit are sent together, synchronization can never be interrupted with part of a consistency unit applied.

A set of continuous item identifiers to which the same clock vector applies. A range is represented by a starting point, an ending point, and a clock vector that applies to all IDs that are in between.

The minimal unit of change tracking in a store. In change propagation, only the units that are changed must be sent; whereas, in conflict detection, independent changes to the same unit are considered a conflict.

The method that is used to determine which change is written to the store in the event of a conflict. Typical conflict resolution methods are as follows: last writer wins, source wins, destination wins, custom, or deferred. For custom resolution, the resolving application reads the conflict from the conflict log and selects a resolution. For deferred resolution, the conflict is logged together with the conflicting change data and the made-with knowledge of the change.
A pair of values, consisting of a replica key and a tick count, that represents a change to a replica.
A measurement of a user’s perception of the quality of an audio communication session. For example, in a voice communication, QoE monitors echoes and background noises such as hissing in the line.
A measurement of a user’s perception of the quality of an audio communication session. For example, in a voice communication, QoE monitors echoes and background noises such as hissing in the line.
The size of the sheet of paper on which you print the publication, before trimming.
The process of applying changes from one replica to another.
A display mode that shows as much content as possible by hiding elements such as navigation and toolbars.
A control that can add functional handles to a visual element that enable a user to manipulate the element in some way (resize, rotate, reposition, etc.).

A type of resource record in the Domain Name System that associates a computer's true (canonical) name with any alias names also used by the computer. Some domain registrars use CNAME records to redirect or redelegate domain names.

The owner of the customer relationship with customers who buy second-level domains. There may be many registrars for a single top-level domain. Registrars maintain detailed customer information in their databases, such as the customer's contact address, telephone number, and e-mail address. Customers usually manage their second-level domains at the registrar's Web site, and the registrar updates the registry database when necessary (for example, when a customer renews a domain name).

A type of resource record in the Domain Name System (DNS) specifying how Internet e-mail should be routed using the Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP). Each MX record contains a preference and a host name, so that the collection of MX records for a given domain name point to the servers that should receive e-mail for that domain, and their priority relative to each other.

A setting that compensates for the color of light in which a picture was taken. A correct white balance setting makes colors look natural, while an incorrect white balance can result in pictures that have exaggerated colors.
A Microsoft volume licensing contract available for small and mid-sized companies that provides a license grant on a subscription basis.
The contractual provisions and major terms agreed to by the parties to an agreement.
The part of a telephone that includes a speaker and a voice transmitter and that you hold with your hand up to your ear.
A UI element the user presses to agree to an incoming file transfer, invitation, audio/video call, or application sharing.
To answer an instant message.
To change the modality of a conversation from, say, voice call to video, starting from a pop-up notification.

A person who works for a call center and signs in to an ACD system or who responds to calls routed to him or her by an IVR system. Formal agents may be signed in into UC throughout the day, and they may sign in and out of the ACD system during the day. They are fully aware of their role as an agent and want to be able to see the numbers of calls in the queues they are serving, and so on. Informal agents may not consider themselves as agents, and they don’t sign in and out of the ACD system as agents. They do not monitor queue fill levels or other metrics.
An automated telephone information system that interacts with a caller through fixed voice menus and real-time data from databases.
An automated telephone information system that interacts with a caller through fixed voice menus and real-time data from databases.
To end a phone call.
A virtual waiting area where conference call invitees are held before the conference is activated. The invitees perceive that they are on hold.
The microphone and speaker on a calling device/phone that allows you to converse with someone without using the handset or headset.
The microphone and speaker on a calling device/phone that allows you to converse with someone without using the handset or headset.
A current attempt by a second party to establish communication with a user.
To take action to not answer a call. The call goes to voice mail if that service is available.
The person who is calling another person or place.
To accept an incoming telephone call.
To combine a series of elements into an individual, larger one, such as a series of photos into one panoramic photo.
A picture made by combining a series of photos into one large picture to provide a complete view of an area or location that cannot fit in a single shot.

Meeting an organization's various obligations, which may arise from laws, regulations, rules, and many other legal instruments, such as court judgments, litigation, and even contracts. Specific and important examples of these obligations include the Sarbanes-Oxley Act (SOX) and the California Law on Notice of Security Breach, formerly known as SB-1386. These regulatory obligations may be created by many sources, such as national and local governments and from industry-specific oversight groups, such as the Payment Card Industry Data Security Standards.
Person responsible for ensuring that an organization complies with the various regulations and standards that are imposed by government and other regulatory bodies.
A collection of communications (e-mail, IM, text messaging, voice mail, and so on) between two or more participants.
A short alphanumeric message that is sent between mobile phones or devices using the SMS protocol.
A short alphanumeric message that is sent between mobile phones or devices using the SMS protocol.
A short alphanumeric message that is sent between mobile phones or devices using the SMS protocol.
A short alphanumeric message that is sent between mobile phones or devices using the SMS protocol.

Private information that a customer provides to establish their Windows Live ID. This information is separate from the customer's (outward-facing) profile and is never shared without explicit consent.

Private information that a customer provides to establish their Windows Live ID. This information is separate from the customer's (outward-facing) profile and is never shared without explicit consent.
An account where customers manage their payments, dues, invoicing, and contact information for paid Microsoft services. These accounts are managed on the Billing and Account Management website.
Information, such as name, billing address, and payment method, related to paying for account services.
The usually pretrial disclosure of pertinent facts or documents by one or both parties to a legal action or proceeding.
The usually pretrial disclosure of pertinent facts or documents by one or both parties to a legal action or proceeding.

Extra information displayed to a user while they are composing an e-mail message. MailTips are displayed in an InfoBar, similar to the banner that appears saying "This message has not been sent." MailTips reveal anything that might be unexpected about the delivery or audience of the message, such as recipient validity or Out of Office status or whether the message might not be delivered.
A template that automatically populates multiple mailbox properties when a mailbox is created in the service. A mailbox plan also assigns default permissions to the corresponding user account.
A policy that specifies the length of time during which data, documents, and other records must be available for recovery.
A collection of Exchange features, organization-wide resource limits, and permissions that are automatically configured or applied when a new hosted organization is provisioned in the service.
A button that stops the task in progress and returns to the previous state.
The act of supplying and configuring computing resources.
A communication technology based on short range (4cm or less) wireless data exchange.
A communication technology based on short range (4cm or less) wireless data exchange.
A navigation bar item that links to billing-related information.
A feature of Hyper-V that allows a running virtual machine to be managed remotely through an interactive session.
A plug-in that users download to run a Silverlight-based application in their browser. This term also refers to the component embedded in a Web page that renders Silverlight content.
Pertaining to a type or member that accesses secure resources and can only be used by fully trusted code in the .NET Framework.

A set of subsystems and interfaces that form a common structure from which a stream of derivative products can be efficiently developed and produced. A given product may have platform deliverables (building blocks) from several areas that define its implementation.
The window that displays solutions, projects, and files, as well as access to the commands that pertain to them.
The computer that manages the OneCare settings for all computers in a OneCare circle.
The computer that manages the OneCare settings for all computers in a OneCare circle.

A computer that receives an action specified by the OneCare administrator. For example, a computer that is the designated the place for file backup would be considered to be the "target PC" of the backup function.
An internal marker used to mark the beginning and the end of a chapter to help navigate DVDs or videos.
A Microsoft volume licensing contract designed for large companies and government organizations that provides a license grant on a non-perpetual basis.
An enrollment signed under an Enterprise Subscription Agreement by the entity that signed the Enterprise Subscription Agreement or one of its affiliates.
A value-added tax levied in some countries/regions.
A monetary amount that may be set against an entity or individual's tax liability.
The information provided with a product by a manufacturer describing how to use a product.
To tap a device screen and hold one's finger or stylus in place.
To tap a device screen and hold one's finger or stylus in place.
A telephone message delivered to a voicemail system.
A program that extends the capabilities of Internet Explorer.
A list or outline of things to be done or considered.
A card, inserted into a portable device, used to store files.

A collection of visual elements and sounds for your computer desktop or device User Interface. A theme determines the look of the various visual elements of your User Interface, such as windows, icons, fonts, and colors, and it can include sounds.

An Internet Explorer feature that allows users to surf the Web without leaving a browsing history, cookies or other information on the PC so they can do online banking on a shared computer, for example.
A service for wireless products that allows users to send and receive brief messages consisting of text and numbers to and from mobile phones and devices.
A computer that is part of a OneCare circle but is not a hub PC or a monitor PC. A device PC has no privileges to monitor or make changes to any other computer in the OneCare circle.

A virtual community that provides people with opportunities to interact (via blogs, chats, newsgroups, webcasts, user groups, and forums) with Microsoft employees, experts, and peers in order to share knowledge and news about Microsoft technology.
The sound made by a mobile device or other phone to indicate an incoming call or message, for example, a series of beeps or an audio recording.
An alert that is set by the user to be activated at a particular time.
A renamed .cab file which contains a .theme file, and optionally one or more desktop backgrounds, icons, mouse pointer files, and sound files. It does not contain executables or screen savers.
A folder that stores the user's graphics, e.g. digital pictures. Many graphic design and photo-editing programs use this location by default to open or save graphic files.

A series of digital-media files that users can subscribe to online, that are sent to their computers and that can then be accessed on demand on the users' reader. The majority of podcasts are available as audio files in MP3 format, syndicated through an RSS (XML) file. Other formats and other types of files, such as video, can also be podcasted.

A mechanism that is used to deliver messages at an interim hop, along the least-cost routing path. A backoff occur when direct relay fails for any reason, such as network issues or servers going offline. The routing component tries to deliver messages as close to the destination as possible by backing off, hop by hop, along the least-cost routing path until a connection is made.

A mailbox that represents conference rooms and company equipment. Resource mailboxes can be included as resources in meeting requests, providing a simple and efficient way to utilize resources for an organization. The user account that is associated with a resource mailbox is disabled.
To monitor an e-mail conversation or newsgroup thread. The headers for messages in a watched conversation appear in a different color, which makes them easier to find in a message list.

A comprehensive PC maintenance center that provides the user with a single point of entry for tasks and notifications associated with PC Health, i.e. security, diagnostics, problem reports and solutions, how to update the system (Windows Updates), performance, reliability, backup and restore, and complete PC backup (recovery and Rescue my PC).
A group of computers on a home network that can share pictures, music, videos, documents, and printers. A homegroup is created by using the HomeGroup feature; it is protected with a password.
A password that helps prevent unauthorized access to homegroup files and printers.
An action that removes redundant messages from an e-mail conversation to reduce information overload and improve readability.
A note you type on the Notes tab of a conversation window to potentially be forwarded along with the call and saved in the call history.
An instant message session with multiple parties, exchanged via IM (not through your mobile operator).
An instant message session with multiple parties, exchanged via IM (not through your mobile operator).
An instant message session with multiple parties, exchanged via IM (not through your mobile operator).
A flag that can be set for Lync and Communicator calls or instant messages to indicate the urgency of the conversation.
A proprietary phone connected to a PBX.
A menu item that opens an Outlook meeting invitation prepopulated with the selected contact(s).
A menu item that marks the selected contact so the user will receive presence alerts when this contact's presence changes from anything to Available or from anything to Unavailable.

termGrp.term: Marca per a avisos de canvi d'estat

descripGrp.descrip: A collection of items, such as files and folders, assembled from various locations. The locations might be on your computer, an external hard drive, removable media, or someone else’s computer.
To fix an item, such as a tile, library, movie, game, or app, in a given area of the UI, so it is always accessible in that area (e.g., to make a library always visible in the navigation pane).
To remove an item, such as a tile, library, movie, game, or app, from a given area of the UI, to make it inaccessible in that area (e.g. to make a library non-visible in the navigation pane).
A person who manages accounts and determines safety settings.
A Windows Live account that manages a subscription.

A device that receives an action specified by the OneCare administrator. For example, an external hard drive that is the designated the place for file backup would be considered to be the "target device" of the backup function.
The standard display text for mailto: link for sending a link to a page, typically used when asking someone to view but not participate in something.

Someone who has been specified by a manager (or other person) to make or receive calls on their behalf. Delegates can change call forwarding settings and add other delegates. Delegates are automatically given “Team Access,” which allows them to contact the “manager” even when his or her presence is set to Do not Disturb.
A pencil tool that works with texture and simulates a real life pencil in stroke.
A Windows feature that enables users to easily roll back their PC to an earlier good state while keeping their data safe.
A Microsoft Outlook add-in that allows you to schedule a Live Meeting or Lync or Office Communicator conference call from Outlook.

termGrp.term: Complement per a conferències per al Microsoft Outlook

descripGrp.descrip: A conversation that is used to share data between conversation members using a non-Communicator application or plug-in.
Dial in to the audio conferencing provider from your physical telephone when the audio conferencing provider service cannot call you.
Pertaining to a connection, session, or call that has, unintentionally or not, ended.
A contact within a group in the Contacts list.
A video stream from a source that is external to the user's computer.
The ability to send and receive calls on a desktop phone by using a computer-supported telecommunications application, such as Lync or Communicator.
A frame that contains text, shapes, pictures, or other content. A slide is a digital equivalent to a traditional film slide.
To mark an e-mail conversation so that all current and future messages in the conversation are automatically moved to the Deleted Items folder.
A console for call handling.
A group of people who can answer calls on behalf of someone else.
A call to a call group that rings the group owner and call group simultaneously. When a member of the group answers the call, the other members get a notification with the status of the call.
A user's work day hours as specified in Microsoft Office Outlook by the day of the week and the start and end times.
To create a sound, vibration, visual cue, or any other indication that the user has an incoming call.
A contact who uses an instant messenger client from AOL, Yahoo!, MSN, or the Windows Live network of Internet services.
The auto-reply text specified using Outlook's Automatic Replies or Out of Office Assistant.
The auto-reply text specified using Outlook's Automatic Replies or Out of Office Assistant.

A feature that merges public switched telephone network (PSTN) and Voice over IP (VoIP) conferences, which allows participants to dial in to a conference from anywhere as an authenticated user without having to be on the corporate network. Typically, a local number is provided to avoid long-distance fees.
An internally or externally hosted service for users to host multiparty conferences from their computers.
A feature that allows the user to apply custom or default markers to items (e.g. Outlook messages or OneNote content) in order to categorize information for easy retrieval and sorting.
A feature that allows the user to apply custom or default markers to items (e.g. Outlook messages or OneNote content) in order to categorize information for easy retrieval and sorting.
A feature in Internet Explorer that helps detect phishing websites and can help protect you from installing malicious software or malware.
The process of creating and sending text messages between or to mobile phones and devices using the SMS protocol.

Any hardware or software that can detect events or environmental changes, such as your current location or the amount of light around your computer. For example, a notebook with a location sensor, such as a Global Positioning System (GPS) receiver, can determine your exact location. An ambient light sensor can detect when there is a change in lighting, and then a program can use that information to adjust the brightness of your screen.

A device that includes an antenna, a radio receiver, and a processor for use with the worldwide GPS (Global Positioning System). A GPS receiver uses position and time information from four GPS satellites to calculate precise information about its current location, its speed of travel, and the current time.
A category of sensor that can detect the current location of your computer.
A library of controls that support user interface development. Some of these controls function as containers for other controls or content, such as images and media.
An area within the Windows Control Panel that provides support for sensors such as enabling, disabling or uninstalling sensors and sensor-enabled applications, changing sensor settings, etc.
A type of light sensor that tracks ambient light in the surroundings and therefore the amount of backlight needed for the LCD screen to be adjusted accordingly.
An arrangement of search results ordered by relevance using a special search algorithm.
An option in Microsoft Virtual Earth that allows the user to view an object in a 45-degree angle from above in bird's eye view.

A radio navigation system developed by the U.S. Department of Defense that uses a constellation of 24 earth satellites, which are monitored by ground-based control stations, to provide precise, continuous worldwide positioning and timing information.
A single set of sign-in credentials (typically, e-mail address and password) that is used to access the services provided by an online service provider (OSP).
A type of search that returns richer results such as graphics and images, helping you find exactly what you’re looking for, quickly and easily.
The process of maintaining connectivity outside of one's usual service or coverage area.
A connection that enables the transmission of data.
A call that originates from your mobile device.
A collaborative action, such as sharing, calendar sharing, or using a whiteboard.
An item on the user's Status menu. A user can select this status to indicate that they are not actively using their computer.
A menu item that enables the user to add a word marked as a misspelling to the dictionary used by the spelling checker.
E-mail that a customer does not want delivered to their inbox, including spam and phishing messages (identified by the mail service) and messages from blocked senders and domains.
E-mail that a customer does not want delivered to their inbox, including spam and phishing messages (identified by the mail service) and messages from blocked senders and domains.
The version that uses checkboxes and does not include a reading pane. It is recommneded for users with a slow internet connection.

A set of colors and background images that lets users change the appearance of Windows Live pages. The theme is common to all pages, except for group, event, and space pages, which may each have their own theme.
To copy something from a computer to a location online, such as a photo album or a blog post.
Parental consent for a child to use a Windows Live service, view a website, or communicate with a person.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to show nonsequential information.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to show steps in a process or timeline.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to show a continual process.

A post, comments, and responses made within a conversation space, such as a message board, help board, community, newsgroup, or blog. These exchanges are usually publicly viewable. Participation may require credentials, such as a Windows Live ID.

The descriptive information about a user that is shown to other users. This editable information is separate from the registration information they provide to establish their Windows Live account. This separation allows users to disclose or conceal personal information as they choose.

The descriptive information about a user that is shown to other users. This editable information is separate from the registration information they provide to establish their Windows Live account. This separation allows users to disclose or conceal personal information as they choose.
An answer that only the user knows for a specific question. The answer is used to confirm someone's identity if they forget their password.
An e-mail address to which password reset information can be sent if a customer forgets the password portion of their Windows Live ID.

A customized message that someone sets in Windows Live Messenger, on Windows Live Home, or on their profile page. The status message is part of the "share anything" control. The information is distributed to any connected service.

A customized message that someone sets in Windows Live Messenger, on Windows Live Home, or on their profile page. The status message is part of the "share anything" control. The information is distributed to any connected service.
A function that allows a user to call a computer.
A menu item that enables users to initiate operations, such as sending an instant message or playing a game.

A horizontal grouping of actions that apply to the container (or containers) with which the toolbar is associated. For example, a container in which mail is viewed might have an action toolbar with options that include Reply, Delete, and Move to.
The user role that is assigned to a user account, which determines the options that are visible to that user and the tasks that the user can perform in the management interface for Exchange Labs.
The user role that is assigned to a user account, which determines the options that are visible to that user and the tasks that the user can perform in the management interface for Exchange Labs.

termGrp.term: funció de control d'accés segons les funcions

descripGrp.descrip: The user role that is assigned to a user account, which determines the options that are visible to that user and the tasks that the user can perform in the management interface for Exchange Labs.
A service that enables customers to implement Windows Live communication services within their own personal domains.

A character code with a null value; literally, a character meaning "nothing." Although it is real in the sense of being recognizable, occupying space internally in the computer, and being sent or received as a character, a NUL character displays nothing, takes no space on the screen or on paper, and causes no specific action when sent to a printer. In ASCII, NUL is represented by the character code 0.
The person whom, or place that, a caller is calling.
A recognition feature that helps increase input speed and reduce effort by providing users with word completion and next word prediction alternates as the user is writing/typing.
An extension of the conventional touch input feature to allow multiple fingers touching the computer or device screen at the same time.
A multi-touch gesture that consists of one or two fingers moving in the same direction, parallel to each other.
A multi-touch gesture that consists of one or two fingers moving in the same direction, parallel to each other.
A multi-touch gesture that consists of two fingers moving in opposite directions (-> <- or <- ->).
A multi-touch gesture that consists of two fingers moving around a center point or one finger moving around a finger that is not moving.
The worldwide collection of networks and gateways that use the TCP/IP suite of protocols to communicate with one another.
The worldwide collection of networks and gateways that use the TCP/IP suite of protocols to communicate with one another.
A collection of computing resources such as programs and virtual desktops that enable a user to accomplish a set of related tasks.

The entity that offers a remote workspace, typically the IT department of the user’s employer, a business partner or vendor, or less commonly, a commercial application service provider. The publisher may use a digital certificate to represent its identity and use it to sign the remote resource files (e.g. RDP files) and the workspace description (e.g. Web Service feed).
A unique identifier made from four otherwise separate pieces of information. For example, a color can be specified by a black, yellow, magenta and cyan quad.
To make an object, such as a file, accessible.
The process of adding geospatial metadata (e.g. longitude, latitude) to media (e.g. Websites, RSS feeds, or images).
The ability of software to support customer-preferred algorithms for encryption, hashing, entropy and digital signatures.
The ability of software to support customer-preferred algorithms for encryption, hashing, entropy and digital signatures.
To remove a user's changes from the Microsoft Office Document Cache without deleting the file on the server or removing the latest version downloaded from the server from the Office Document Cache.
The feature that forwards a call from a team leader to an entire team according to a hunt group algorithm.
A mode of Windows Photo Viewer which consists of a top level window displaying one photograph at a time, with navigation controls.
A recordable media (such as CD-RW) to which you can only write once without reformatting.
A recordable media to which you can write several times without reformatting.
A feature that is added to the Microsoft Office Compatibility Pack to open Word, Excel, and PowerPoint binary format files and securely convert them to the Office 2007 file formats.

To remove data permanently from a storage medium. This is usually done by replacing existing data with zeros or meaningless text or, in magnetic media, by disturbing the magnetic particles' physical arrangement, either with the erase head or with a large magnet.
A note that contains recorded information.
A central hub for viewing pending uploads to http servers (mainly SharePoint) and correcting upload errors.
A central hub for viewing pending uploads to http servers (mainly SharePoint) and correcting upload errors.

termGrp.term: Centre de càrrega del Microsoft Office

descripGrp.descrip: A central hub for viewing pending uploads to http servers (mainly SharePoint) and correcting upload errors.
To establish a Bluetooth link or connection between two Bluetooth–enabled devices.
To make a single file out of a set of files using a program such as compress, gzip, or PKZIP.
A radio network that provides coverage for cellular telephone communications.

To copy driver binaries, install services, and add registry keys for one or more drivers from a driver package onto a system, without the context of a specific device. A system can be booted from reflected drivers, however full device installation may still be required in order to enable full driver functionality.

An account that has restricted functionality. In Windows Live, these accounts are designed for children under the age of 13 and provide a limited set of features. For example, restricted accounts don't have permission to synchronize libraries across computers.
A helper bot for Windows Live Messenger that was developed on the Windows Live Agents platform.

A full-page UI view that exposes file-level functionality in Office applications. This is a companion feature to the Office Ribbon and helps users discover and use the features that fall outside of the authoring features on the Ribbon.
A list of the alerts that a Windows Live Messenger customer has received.
A feature that allows someone to manage their Windows Live alerts.
A personal web presence provided by the Windows Live Spaces service.
The helper program that can store sign-in information for multiple Windows Live IDs.

termGrp.term: Ajudant d'inici de sessió de Windows Live

descripGrp.descrip: A slide show of MSN videos that displays in the advertising space of the main Main messenger window.
A file, similar to a video clip, that contains a short audio segment that a user records to send to a contact. The clip appears in the contact's conversation window and plays automatically.
A list that displays someone's recent activity on Windows Live.
The link to the webpage where a user manages photos and albums.
The process of establishing a Bluetooth link or connection between two Bluetooth–enabled devices.
A Windows library that allows users to store, manage and share all their recorded TV items.
The use of Web sites and services that provide enhanced information and interaction capabilities with regard to people and resources.
The process of dynamically rearranging a hierarchy of SharePoint sites, typically used during a migration.
The process of dynamically rearranging a hierarchy of SharePoint sites, typically used during a migration.
A Windows feature that provides a direct connection to a corporate network for people working outside of the office. It is a superior alternative to VPN.
A PC (desktop and beyond) search platform that allows search of the local hard drive plus network locations like SharePoint sites and the Internet.
A set of attributes that define a user's access to a given service or application.
To break a connection.
To call the last person called from a phone or device.
To send text messages from a mobile phone or device.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to compare or show the relationship between two ideas. Each of the first two lines of Level 1 text corresponds to text at the top of one side of the center point. Emphasizes Level 2 text, which is limited to four shapes on each side of the center point. The balance tips towards the side with the most shapes containing Level 2 text. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.
The process of customizing the look and feel of a product to support marketing or promotion of another company.

Not able to be delivered to an intended recipient. If an e-mail message is undeliverable, it is returned to the sender with information added by the mail server explaining the problem; for example, the e-mail address may be incorrect, or the recipient's mailbox may be full.
To reject or turn off a system notification such as a reminder, a new message alert or an alarm.
A telephone call the user has failed to answer.
As set of rules defined by the administrator. For example, the policy may require all users to change their passwords.
A company that provides services or content for its customers.
The act of sending the current phone call to a third person.
A menu item that transfers the current phone call without the user remaining on the line to announce the call.
A Windows Phone application that is both a digital still camera and a digital video camera.
An occurrence, activity or happening of significance that occurs.
The on-screen representation of the phone keypad or dial pad on the device.
The mechanical part that makes the phone ring to indicate an incoming call.
A type of personal identification number (PIN) for the SIM card, consisting of 4 digits, that is used to gain access to your mobile phone.
To expose a virtual disk to the user, backed by a file.

A computer that works with data in groups of 32 bits at a time. The Apple Macintosh II and higher models are 32-bit machines, in terms of both the word size of their microprocessors and the size of the data buses, as are computers based on the Intel 80386 and higher-level microprocessors.
To uninstall all software on a computer and reinstall a new Windows image.
A small pop-up window that informs users of a non-critical problem or special condition in a control.
A category of sensor that may use all or some of the following applied stimulus to detect movement: ultrasound, infrared, heat and vibration.
A biometric sensor that analyses your eye retina to recognize or authenticate identity.
A category of sensor that can respond to an applied stimulus by generating an electrical signal.
A category of sensor that is used for mechanical measurement of force, scale, pressure, strain, etc.
A category of sensor that tracks environmental changes such as temperature, atmospheric pressure, humidity, wind speed and wind direction.
A type of sensor that can determine without physical contact if an object/person is nearby, or can be used to measure the distance between the object/person and the sensor device.

A type of sensor (such as a proximity sensor) that uses radio frequency identification (RFID) for a numerous purposes, such as identification of physical items, automatic log on, location of people, etc.
A category of sensor that responds to a pre-defined amount of light.
An Internet site that provides a collection of products and services developed by Microsoft partners for Microsoft Office users.
To remove a Bluetooth link or connection between two Bluetooth–enabled devices.
A view mode in Internet Explorer that determines whether content is rendered as if users were viewing it in a previous version of Internet Explorer.
An Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) 802.11 wireless network in which Service Set Identifier (SSID) suppression is enabled.

A feature that prevents Internet Explorer from storing data about your browsing session. This helps prevent anyone else who might be using your computer from seeing where you visited and what you looked at on the Web.
The feature that blocks third-party web content that could potentially track someone's web activity.

A form of IIS authentication in which IIS accepts client-certificates used to prove the client's identity. Using this form of authentication, IIS can optionally map a client certificate to a Windows user account by using an internal mapping table or Active Directory.

An image and color combination designed to personalize a display window that is viewable to other people. For example, in Windows Live Messenger, someone can choose from a set of available scenes, or upload their own background image. They can also use a default color suggestion, or specify their own color. Someone's personalization is displayed in the main Messenger window (visible to themselves) and also in the main conversation window (visible to others).
The link group that includes links to the About Hotmail webpage, the What's New webpage, and so on.
The API that defines a set of web services which can programmatically access the Windows Live Contacts Address Book database.

termGrp.term: API dels Contactes del Windows Live

descripGrp.descrip: The Windows Live service for event planning and invitations.
The set of Windows Live services optimized for use on mobile devices running Windows Mobile.

termGrp.term: Windows Live per a Windows Mobile

descripGrp.descrip: The Windows Live webpage that displays security and safety-related activities.
The OneCare software designed to run on supported servers.

The link that appears above an incomplete content set and leads to the full list of items. For example, when a content module displays items 1–6, a "View all" link in line with the module label leads to a webpage that lists all items. The items that are available in preview are redundantly available in the list of all items, which may be paginated.
A webpage link saved as a .url file in someone's "Shared favorites" folder. For example, shared favorites can be created directly within OneDrive, or via the Windows Live Toolbar.
The image that appears in the conversation window.
A contribution or feedback left by someone viewing content on a site. Someone who views a space, photos, or files can leave a comment, if permissions allow it.
A computer that belongs to a homegroup.
A troubleshooter that helps find and fix problems with viewing computers or shared files in a homegroup.
To group together multiple windows of the same application under a single button on the taskbar’s taskband.
A zoom out gesture represented by two fingers with at least one of them moving towards the other finger at any angle, within an acceptable tolerance.
A zoom out gesture represented by two fingers with at least one of them moving towards the other finger at any angle, within an acceptable tolerance.
A zoom-in gesture represented by two fingers with at least one of them moving away from each other at any angle, within an acceptable tolerance.
A zoom-in gesture represented by two fingers with at least one of them moving away from each other at any angle, within an acceptable tolerance.
A software or device that helps control your home smart devices automatically.

An input device used chiefly for identification purposes that reads information that has been magnetically encoded, usually in two tracks, on a plastic card, such as a credit card or an employee badge.
A notebook that is smaller in size and lighter in weight than a full-sized notebook, while retaining the same functionality.
A primary storage device based on solid-state memory, such as flash memory, that provides nonvolatile storage with benefits of performance, reliability and power saving.
A node that makes cached data available to clients needing to retrieve the data.
To apply a skin to an existing user interface.
To apply a marker to content or items (like photos or text) to identify certain types of information.
A customizable dictionary for each user that is empty by default. Users can add typed or handwritten words to and remove them from the user dictionary.
An authoritative source for an attribute value that can flow its value to other destination directories and systems.

A COM-based multimedia platform and infrastructure for digital media in Microsoft Windows. It focuses on content protection, audio and video quality, and interoperability for digital rights management (DRM).

A COM-based multimedia platform and infrastructure for digital media in Microsoft Windows. It focuses on content protection, audio and video quality, and interoperability for digital rights management (DRM).
A calendar that displays all of the birthdays stored in someone's contact list.

A website whose content is understandable and usable by kids and that is appropriate for them. The language is typically aimed at a grade-school reading level, and the concepts presented are accessible to younger minds.

A website whose content is understandable and usable by kids and that is appropriate for them. The language is typically aimed at a grade-school reading level, and the concepts presented are accessible to younger minds.

termGrp.term: pàgina web amigable per a nens

descripGrp.descrip: A website whose content is understandable and usable by kids and that is appropriate for them. The language is typically aimed at a grade-school reading level, and the concepts presented are accessible to younger minds.

termGrp.term: pàgina web apropiada per a nens

descripGrp.descrip: The tab on the Family Safety website that displays requests a child has made via e-mail to view a blocked website.
The tab on the Family Safety website that displays requests a child has made via e-mail to have new contacts added.
A method of blocking access to websites based on their content. For example, In Windows Live Family Safety, parents can specify a filtering level, such as Strict or Basic, for their child.
A person authorized to manage and make certain changes to a group, such as to approve a membership request.

The panel item the image-leveling feature in Windows Live Photo Gallery. When the item is clicked, the feature automatically adjusts the photo according to its best interpretation of the horizontal axis. It also displays a slider, which allows someone to make further adjustments. The photo is automatically cropped as needed.
To adjust the axis of a photo so that objects in the photo appear level, typically with use of an image editing tool.
The panel item that opens the image editing tool that enables the user to apply a black and white effect.

A search location exposed via .osdx templates and made possible via the OpenSearch technology. It connects the local search indexer to a remote index and provides the end user with the ability to search for files on a Web site or on an intranet site from within Windows.
A Web site from Microsoft which provides solutions for the top issues about Windows Update or Microsoft Update, and enables you to contact a support professional.

termGrp.term: Centre de solucions del Microsoft Update

descripGrp.descrip: A viewer that allows users to display Excel workbooks on a phone’s browser. A file is rendered as an HTML page with sufficient fidelity to convey important data or charts and illustrations.

termGrp.term: Visualitzador de l'Excel per a mòbil

descripGrp.descrip: A viewer that allows users to display Word documents on a phone’s browser. A file is rendered as an HTML page with sufficient fidelity to convey text and images on a small screen.

termGrp.term: Visualitzador del Word per a mòbil

descripGrp.descrip: A telephone that sits on a desk and is to be used with Lync Server and Office Communications Server.
To gain access to all phone functionality by entering the correct password when the phone has locked itself due to delayed use or when the user has manually locked it.
A numeric keypad that is part of a device, is displayed on a device, or is in a computer program that you use to enter information in the context of a phone call.
The process of creating a hyperlink to a specific page within a Web site or Web-based application instead of to the site’s home page.

An icon that is attached to an event and that is viewable in someone's calendar. Depending on the calendar view, a charm may appear next to an event title, or may be the only visual representation of an event on a calendar day.
An e-mail message that is sent by a notification activity.
A part of a schema that defines the representation of a resource in ILM "2".
An element of a filter that specifies a relationship between data values, such as comparison or equality.
A procedure by which a user's password can be changed to a known value, in situations where the user has forgotten or lost their password.

One of a group of photo modifications someone can make to a color photo that mimic different effects that would be achieved by taking the same photo using black and white film stock. One effect uses strict conversion to monochrome by throwing away all of the color information. Others mimic the result when a black and white photo is taken through a colored filter—orange, red, or yellow—to enhance or suppress certain color information. Two effects perform strict conversions to monochrome and then apply a color tint—sepia or cyan—in one step.
The set of Windows Live services available for use on mobile devices.
A user interface implemented by a software application via a component of a web server, such as IIS.
A running instance of a workflow definition, when a request is made.
To permit someone else to perform an action. For example, to let someone else see your online status, send you messages, or see your public Messenger information.

A microprocessor architecture developed in 1992 by Motorola and IBM, with some participation by Apple. A PowerPC microprocessor is RISC-based and superscalar, with a 64-bit data bus and 32-bit address bus. It also has separate data and instruction caches, although the size of each varies by implementation. All PowerPC microprocessors have multiple integer and floating-point units. The voltage and operating speed varies with the implementation. Starting with the PowerPC 740, the microprocessors were manufactured with copper, instead of aluminum, for better performance and reliability.
A navigation button used to return to recently visited Web pages in Internet Explorer and other internet browsers.
A staging area that contains representations of selected objects and attributes in a connected data source.
The data store that is used by ILM to contain the aggregated identity information from multiple connected data sources, providing a single global, integrated view of all combined objects.
A remote filing system protocol that provides a standard means for a workstation on an AppleTalk network to access and manipulate files on an AFP-implemented server.

A software system that retrieves information from a source data store and synchronizes (pushes) to a target data store. Examples of synchronization engines are the ILM 2007 and FIM 2010 synchronization engines, and the service that synchronizes data rows in the SQL Server Express database with objects in the Microsoft Office Outlook data store.
To refuse to accept a file or message.
A service that enables applications to provide their own logon UI and to verify credentials independently.
A set of components and services that enable users to access their Exchange mailboxes through the Outlook Web Access application.
A term that can be added to a search to filter the results by a specific property (for example, by author). Relevant search filters appear under the search box in any open folder.
A collection of Internet Protocol subnets, usually used to connect a group of computers that are physically close to each other.
A set of sign-in credentials (username and password) for an Active Directory account.
The identity of a user, which can be used to grant access to resources or authority to perform certain tasks.

A soft keyboard that is displayed with a different set of settings by default (larger buttons, bigger size, etc.) when you launch the Tablet PC Input Panel with touch. This is to facilitate touch input.
A small, affordable laptop that is designed to perform a limited number of tasks such as web browsing and e-mail.
A real-time, physical action applied to an object, in which multiple contact points are used simultaneously.
A feature that simplifies the task of creating new SharePoint data. It makes it easier for users to enter free-form information or add photos, Web Parts or files to a SharePoint page.
A company that provides servers, Internet connectivity, and other associated facilities needed to publish websites.
A mobile phone that can view web content by connecting directly to the Internet.

termGrp.term: telèfon mòbil habilitat per a Internet

descripGrp.descrip: The heading for information about the time at which something was added, changed, or re-posted.
A number used as a unique identifier for each Windows Live ID holder. This number is disclosed to residents of the European Union to comply with EU privacy regulations.
An adjustment made to improve working order or efficiency.
A customizable page that launches with Windows Live Messenger and features a summary of news and weather, allows a customer to preview their Windows Live Mail inbox and search the Internet.
The title of the window in which the Windows Live Messenger Today page is displayed.
The part of a message header that contains the e-mail addresses of the primary recipients of an e-mail message.
A text box where someone enters the e-mail addresses of the primary recipients of an e-mail message.

One of the two unlabeled keys located just below the display area on a mobile phone. These keys are called "soft" because their functions change to fit the context. Labels in the lower part of the mobile screen tell users what the soft keys do.

One of the two unlabeled keys located just below the display area on a mobile phone. These keys are called "soft" because their functions change to fit the context. Labels in the lower part of the mobile screen tell users what the soft keys do.
A feature of Windows Live Toolbar that provides additional information for particular kinds of text someone selects.
To reveal or conceal information on a screen, such as webpage modules or details about a person.
The button that enables someone to simultaneously send the messages they have composed and retrieve the new messages they've received.
A fraudulent business scheme; a swindle.
A feature in Live Search that provides answers to basic search queries, such as "What is the population of Mumbai?"
A map view created from aerial photos that shows buildings, roads, and geographical features.
A form of Launcher that scrolls from right to left and displays both a strip of smaller application icon images on the sides, and a single larger application preview image in the center.
The combination of hardware (touchscreen or touchpad) and software elements that provides a way to control programs by touching multiple points on the screen simultaneously.
A predefined collection of audio files (for example, songs) from a CD or digital download.

In Windows 9x, Windows NT, and Windows 2000, a handle to a Registry key in which configuration information is stored. Each key leads to sub-keys containing configuration information that, in earlier versions of Windows, was stored in .ini files. For example, the handle key HKEY_CURRENT_USERControl Panel leads to the subkey for the Windows Desktop.
The name given to the Macintosh operating system, beginning with version 7.5 in September 1994, when Apple started licensing the software to other computer manufacturers.
Audio and video on a call that are exchanged before the recipient accepts the call. Examples include announcements, requests for input, and caller voice commands.
The street address or geographical coordinates of a user, and (by way of extensions) of the user’s computer or devices.
A specification according to which each open document occupies its own window in the UI, though only a single instance of the program application is running.
A question, usually from a drop-down list, that users can use to confirm their identity and reset their password in case they have forgotten it.
The feature with which a mobile phone user can place a voice call by clicking a contact’s single phone number or Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) URI.
To add something to one's Favorites folder.
The message text box that is displayed on a contact's summary page.
